block.p: U.S. Planning to Cut Forces in South Korea The Bush Administration has presented a detailed plan to South Korea for withdrawing one-third of its 37,000 troops on the divided peninsula by the end of next year as part of a wider effort to reposition American forces worldwide, including Iraq, officials in Seoul and Washington said.

U.S. Sought Torture Loopholes A team of administration lawyers concluded in a March 2003 legal memorandum that President Bush was not bound by either an international treaty prohibiting torture or by a federal antitorture law because he has the authority as commander in chief to approve any technique needed to protect the nation's security.

American and Iraqi officials said they had won commitments from nine of the country's largest militias to disband, but there were immediate indications that the agreement might be difficult to enforce.

While there have been reports of forced nudity of prisoners at other detention facilities, the practice was apparently far more aggressive at Abu Ghraib, according to reports and sworn statements from detainees and soldiers.
The United States said it believed it had the support of the Security Council for its resolution on Iraq and would put the measure to a vote today.

Support for Afghan Leader President Hamid Karzai has accepted the support of the powerful mujahedeen leaders for the presidential elections scheduled for September, indicating he will continue an alliance with them in a future government and dismaying many who had hoped to see an end to the power of the warlords.

Israel and Egypt Meet President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met with the Israeli foreign minister, Silvan Shalom, to discuss a possible role for Egyptian security forces in Israel's proposed withdrawal from the Gaza Strip.

Capital Hustles to Prepare Its Funeral for Reagan Nothing has been left to chance in the 300-page funeral plan for former President Ronald Reagan, but Washington was still scrambling frantically to prepare for the first state presidential funeral since Lyndon B. Johnson's in 1973.
Thousands of Americans walked past a flag-draped coffin at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in tribute to a leader after a service attended by Mrs. Reagan.

Combating Child Abuse Abroad The Bush administration, as part of its more aggressive agenda abroad to protect American interests at home and to combat child abuse, has forged an alliance with humanitarian groups to expose safe havens for so-called sex tourists.
G.O.P. to Mix Church and State Republicans in the House of Representatives have quietly introduced a measure to make it easier for churches to support political candidates.

Scope of C.I.A. May Change The departure of George J. Tenet as director of central intelligence may remove one obstacle to an overhaul that would make him the last person to hold the job in its current form, some members of Congress and the Sept. 11 commission say.

New Hope for Cancer Patients The drug Taxotere can extend the lives of prostate cancer patients after hormonal therapy fails, giving men a new last-ditch option for treatment, according to the results of two clinical trials.

Heir of Pre-Nazi Art Can Sue The Supreme Court ruled that the 88-year-old niece and heir of an Austrian Jewish art collector can pursue her lawsuit against the Austrian government and its national art gallery for the return of six paintings by Gustav Klimt that belonged to her family before the Nazi takeover.

Bloomberg Takes On Noise For a New Code of Silence The Bloomberg administration wants to overhaul the city's noise code for the first time in more than three decades, in an ambitious effort to bring succor to New Yorkers who are tortured by jackhammers, pounding music and the incessant jingles of ice cream trucks.

Home Care Workers Strike Home care agencies scrambled to send nurses or other aides to care for many sick and elderly patients as the city's largest health care union, 1199/S.E.I.U., called a three-day strike, hoping to increase the wages of 23,000 aides.

Construction Worker Killed A construction worker was killed and two others injured at a Queens building site when an eight-foot-high concrete wall suddenly collapsed around them, the authorities said.
Lightning Wins Stanley Cup The Tampa Bay Lightning defeated the Calgary Flames in Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals, 2-1, for the first championship in its young history.

Greenland's Icy Riddle Experts have reported a series of observations in recent months that show that the ice and the waters in Greenland are in a state of profound flux. If the trends persist, they could mean higher sea levels and widespread coastal flooding. There is also a small chance that the changes could lead to a sharp cooling in parts of the Northern Hemisphere.

Microsoft Discloses SAP Talks Microsoft issued a press release saying that it had held discussions last year to buy SAP, the German maker of business software, a disclosure that could affect the antitrust trial involving Oracle's bid for PeopleSoft.

Bank Loan Programs Allowed The Federal Reserve said that banks could continue controversial programs that consumer advocate groups say function as high-cost loans used mainly by poor and middle-income people.
Editorials: Military arithmetic; a fitting tribute to Mr. Reagan; the wrong proliferation message; a stroll across the sun.
